# Functions-Call Basics

ğŸ§  **Concept**  A *function object* is stored code; a *function call* runs it. The parentheses trigger execution. Objects or strings without `()` just print. Type in the following into your R script and run each line. Comment out lines that produce an error. 

```{r , eval=FALSE}
thing_1             # object? (expect an errorâ€‘message: not found)

"thing_1"           # character string â€” prints literally

3                   # numeric literal

mean                # function *object* â†’ prints the function body

mean()              # function *call*   â†’ error: argument is missing
```

ğŸ‘€ Check-in: What happens if you try  sum vs. sum(1:5)  ?

# Using Help

ğŸ” **Why use Help**?  Nobody memorizes every argument. `?function_name` opens the help file.  

Type the following R code into your script. Read the help tab for more about the *Usage* section for defaults, and the *Arguments* list for details.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
?mean               # opens in Help pane (bottom-right)

help(sample)        # alternate syntax works the same
```

ğŸ’¡ Pro-tip:  `args(mean)`  prints the argument names inline.

# Required vs. Default

âš–ï¸ **Key Idea**  If R supplies a default you can omit that argument; if not, you *must* provide it. Use named arguments for clarity. Type the following into your R script and run each line.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
values <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, NA)

mean(values)                       # default na.rm = FALSE â†’ returns NA

mean(values, na.rm = TRUE)         # ignore missing values

mean(values, trim = 0.2, na.rm = TRUE)  # drop 20% from each end first
```

ğŸ“ Identify: Try `median(values, na.rm = TRUE)`. Why doesnâ€™t `median() `need trim?

ğŸ” Look deeper: What is bootstrapping in statistics?

Type the following code in your R script and run each line.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
set.seed(123)          # reproducible randomness

numbers <- 1:10

sample(numbers, 3)                 # three unique picks

sample(numbers, 10, replace = TRUE)  # allow repeats
```

ğŸ’¡ **Idea**  Feed the output of one function straight into another. Type the following R script in your document script and run.

